description: The adjective is a learned borrowing from Latin leporīnus + English -ine (suffix meaning ‘of or pertaining to’). Leporīnus is derived from leporis (the genitive singular form of lepus (“hare”)) + -īnus (suffix meaning ‘of or pertaining to’).
The noun is derived from the adjective.

entries.meaning: (chiefly mammalogy, also figuratively) Of, relating to, or resembling a hare or rabbit.
examples: Synonym: (shaped like a hare or rabbit) leporiform
(hare): Synonyms: harelike, (shaped like a hare) lagomorphic
His leporine ears perked up at the mention of dessert.

entries.meaning: Synonym of leporid (“any mammal of the family Leporidae: the hares and rabbits”)
(historical) A supposed hybrid between a hare and a rabbit, now known not to exist; a leporide.
